message: That's commit messages, not code
I swear in commit messages if it takes too long to find a bug, or if I committed a typo in a previous commit
Quite often. Usually late at night when I've been banging my head against some stupid programming error that's taken me hours to find.
I have a serious mouth on me but my code comments never contain profanity.
If you know it's bad, you shouldn't be writing it.
So no.

I use python and I don't but I could understand it with other languages. What's odd is that this reports that python and php use the least whereas if I would use profanity, it would definitely be in PHP. http://andrewvos.com/2011/02/21/amount-of-profanity-in-git-commit-messages-per-programming-language/
mine tend to only be related to very hackish solutions, or complaining about a language I'm forced to use for a project (php)
Personal sites? Abso-fucking-lutely. For anything work-related I'll strip it out before releasing to a client.
Or when the clients make some boneheaded request and I have to do ridiculous amounts of work to accomodate this 'really simple', entirely new functionality.
fuck no!
or if it's a feature that I didn't want to implement/went over budget on
almost never IN the code though
@issackelly commit messages and also comments.
Oh, I didn't realize that searched comments too
There's a great emotional feeling that comes with swearing out loud that you just don't get when you write/type it. So as much as I like profanities, they don't get within a mile of my code/commits.
Fuck that, really fucking rude and unprofessional shit right there.
Only when appropriate.
fuck yeah!
Hmm, once I created a CSS class for some buttons in my page. I named it 'mybutt'

Back in the 90's, I included profanity in debugging messages on a Macromedia Director CDROM project. I pulled 2 all-nighters in a row, we burned the gold master, and I passed out at home with the phone off the hook. Turned out some of my popup messages were discovered by the company's CEO just as a courier was on the way to fetch the master and take it to a duplicating house so we could meet a deadline. Someone came, banged on my door until I got up, and I returned to work to fix things. I wasn't fired, we made the deadline, and I never ever did that again.

Yes, although I only do it on code that is bad or on code that implements something stupid. So generally it should be avoided and in a business setting I wouldn't do it at all unless more or less encouraged.
